title: 10 spooky spots where it's Halloween all year [Photos]
text:
Friday, October 02, 2015 07:00 AM CDT 10 spooky spots where itâ€™s Halloween all year Previous Next 
Aokigahara Forest, Japan: This Mount Fuji-area forest has been given the unpleasant distinction of being a major destination for suicides, with more than 500 people having killed themselves here since the 1950s. Each year, police comb the forest to look for bodies. More than 100 dead bodies were discovered in 2004. The eerie stillness of the forest and ghosts of those caught in purgatory make this one of the most haunted locations in Asia. ( Wikipedia/ajari ) 
Bran Castle, Romania: Built in 1212, Bran Castle, and, indeed, all of nearby Transylvania, is forever linked to the legends of Dracula. This vampire connection has made Bran Castle and Transylvania a frightening destination year-round. A museum and tours of the castle are available. (Fotolia) emicristea - Fotolia 
Edinburgh Castle, Scotland: Human occupation of Edinburgh Castle, perched atop a rocky perch, dates back to 900 BC. It is now the most visited attraction in Scotland, with more than 1.3 million tourists per year stopping by for a spooky fright. Visitors have reported seeing and hearing strange, otherworldly things during their visit. No doubt the ghosts of those who were imprisoned and tortured remain to haunt visitors. (Fotolia) Brian Jackson - Fotolia 
New Orleans, Louisiana: Discover the ghosts and goblins of New Orleans while on a haunted tour of the French Quarter. Be sure to stop by one of the many voodoo shops around town or join the parties and parades on the famous Bourbon and Frenchmen streets where locals and visitors alike come to play year-round. Anne Rice's vampire novels also have a large connection to New Orleans, likely because the author herself lives in the city. Explore the vampire history of New Orleans for yourself on a vampire-themed tour. (Fotolia) Henry Brown - Fotolia 
Paris, France: The Catacombs in Paris are a network of subterranean tunnels and rooms located in what were Roman-era limestone quarries. As the city grew, the cemeteries quickly ran out of space and the quarries were converted into a mass tomb near the end of the 18th century. Open for visits year-round, the Catacombs are an interesting, if frightening, destination from which to explore the underbelly of one of the world's most visited cities. (Fotolia) heisenberg - Fotolia 
RMS Queen Mary, Long Beach, California: This retired ocean liner turned floating hotel hosts ghost tours to sate the appetites of tourists hungry for a glimpse of the famed hauntings on board. There have been 49 deaths on the ship and guests have reported seeing spirits walking the hallways, swimming in the first-class pool and even manning the engine room. (Fotolia) Charles Kaye - Fotolia 
Salem, Massachusetts: Book your ticket for Salem's Haunted Footsteps Ghost Tour when visiting. The tour shows you sites associated with the ghostly past of Salem, from the witch trials of 1692 to the art of cemeteries. The Salem Witch Museum will provide even more history on the infamous Salem Witch Trials of 1692, one of the most important and tragic events in American history. (Fotolia) jovannig - Fotolia 
Sleepy Hollow, New York: This village, located nearly 50 km north of New York City, is the final resting place of Washington Irving, author of the Sleepy Hollow story. Formerly known as North Tarrytown, the village changed its name in 1996 to honour Irving and the Sleepy Hollow tale. (Fotolia) Matthias Bonk - Fotolia 
Tower of London, England: London offers many ghost tours throughout the year -- don't miss the Jack the Ripper tour, either -- but be sure to visit what is said to be the most haunted spot in England: the Tower of London. The Tower housed prisoners and was the site of many murders and executions, including those of Anne Boleyn, one of the wives of Henry VIII, Lady Jane Grey and the Countess of Salisbury. (Fotolia) Blacky - Fotolia 
Capuchin Catacombs, Palermo, Italy: The bodies in the Capuchin Catacombs are remarkably well-preserved, which have led to this burial site becoming a tourist attraction. About 8,000 mummies line the walls of the catacombs, separated by category: women, men, virgins, children, priests, monks and professionals. (Wikipedia) Article
